title: Almost Figgins Sans?
content:
From a great Berlin exhibition that revolves around the Whole Earth Catalog and its impact. It looks a lot like Nick Shinn's Figgins Sans to me, but it's different in some (obvious) details: ascender-to-cap ratio, the t, the, r, the f... Maybe custom modifications?

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713124857im_/http:/geoarchitecture.files.wordpress.com/2013/04/2013-04-26-11-00-07.jpg?w=960)

![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713124857im_/http:/www.mottodistribution.com/site/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/The-Whole-Earth_01.jpg)
author: lindenhayn

comments.content: PS: for »Figgins Sans« in the above post, we may also substitue Klim's Founders Grotesk: close, but not quite...

Thanks for posting this.  
 I quite like the way the tail in the /a/ gets cut off in the first picture.

Odd the way the tail on the /t/ sharpens as it comes out, much like the a here ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713124857im_/http:/www.maquetteetmiseenpage.fr/files/pasolini_09.jpg) by [Maquette & Mise en Page](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713124857/http:/www.maquetteetmiseenpage.fr/).
Ah, after some fact finding, it's [Grot 10](http://web.archive.org/web/20140713124857/http:/www.a2-type.co.uk/html/grot10.html) by A2-Type

[x]

wonderful! Never heard of Grot 10 before, thanks a lot!

_\> Ah, after some fact finding, it's Grot 10 by A2-Type_

apparently, with a custom, more unobstrusive `ß`.
